Articles.Content:
I made this stock orion for a rocket building company, but I decided to post it here. It uses the Delta V heavy for the launcher though, but it is the right size (5 m).

Javascript is disabled. View full album

http://www./view/rxdci09xh0v58kn/Orion.craft

Without refueling it can reach eeloo and with refueling it can reach mars in rss.

Instructions:

1. hit space

2. hit z

3. hit space

4. wait 44 seconds and set the thrust limiter to 55.5% on the center engine

5. gravity turn at 10,000 m

6. when side boosters run out of fuel hit space

7. set thrust limiter to 100%

8. when you reach 40,000 m do half of the gravity turn done earlier

9. when apogee reaches 70,000 m throttle down to 2/3

10. coast to 75,000 and circularize using next stage when neccessary

(Unecessary step). dock and refuel

11. gravity slingshot by mun or the moon if in rss

12. go to destination

I am working on better fairings and a more realistic size.

Edited November 18, 2014 by LABHOUSE
I like your fairings, maybe at the top make it a bit smoother
Just finished the sls version I am now testing it.
That looks great! Reminds me of the ULA Delta IV, in the series of SLS Nasa crafts. That is one powerful craft!

Looks epic! Just wondering does the fairing affect the stability or the way the rocket flies in stock aerodynamic?

Also how do you put the fuel tanks together like that and still get the fuel to feed into just one engine?

Edited November 27, 2014 by worir4

I used the fuel struts and removed some of the fuel from the outer ones. It does give the rocket a little bit more stability in stock aero but also makes it somewhat difficult/take longer than usual to do a gravity turn.
